abstract.text: A layout object that manages the layout-related attributes for a given item in a collection view.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Layout objects create instances of this class when asked to do so by the collection view. In turn, the collection view uses the layout information to position cells and supplementary views inside its bounds.

In most cases, you use this class as-is. If you want to supplement the base layout attributes with custom layout attributes, you can subclass and define whatever properties you want to store the additional layout data. Because layout attribute objects may be copied by the collection view, make sure your subclass conforms to the
protocol by implementing any methods appropriate for copying your custom attributes to new instances of your subclass. In addition to defining your subclass, your
method so that they can apply any custom attributes at layout time.
If you subclass and implement any custom layout attributes, you must also override the inherited

method to compare the values of your properties. In iOS 7 and later, the collection view doesnâ€™t apply layout attributes if those attributes have not changed. It determines whether the attributes have changed by comparing the old and new attribute objects using the

method. Because the default implementation of this method checks only the existing properties of this class, you must implement your own version of the method to compare any additional properties. If your custom properties are all equal, call
and return the resulting value at the end of your implementation.

abstract.text: A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A view that defines the behavior for all cells and supplementary views presented by a collection view.
Applies the specified layout attributes to the view.
Constants specifying the type of view.
A layout object that organizes items into a grid with optional header and footer views for each section.
A set of properties for determining whether to recompute the size of items or their position in the layout.
An abstract base class for generating layout information for a collection view.
A layout object that manages the layout-related attributes for a given item in a collection view.
The transparency of the item.
The bounds of the item.
The center point of the item.
The frame rectangle of the item.
The index path of the item in the collection view.
Creates and returns a layout attributes object that represents a cell with the specified index path.
Creates and returns a layout attributes object that represents the specified decoration view.
Creates and returns a layout attributes object that represents the specified supplementary view.
Determines whether the item is currently displayed.
The type of the item.
The layout-specific identifier for the target view.
The size of the item.
The affine transform of the item.
The 3D transform of the item.
Specifies the itemâ€™s position on the z axis.
A special type of layout object that lets you implement behaviors when changing from one layout to another in your collection view.
A set of methods that can make a custom object eligible to participate in UIKit Dynamics.
Customize a view layout by changing the size of cells in the flow or implementing a mosaic style.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
